issues.title: Considerations for AEADs
issues.author: OR13
issues.body:
In this rather long thread: https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/jose/GcoCkOeg37tbFmZDkmtc3ExHVeU/

We discussed what fully specified means for HPKE and ECDH-ES+A128KW.

We considered solutions to binding the AEAD to the kdf, and how that is related to the current use of concatKDF, as described in https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7518#section-4.6.2

Note that "AlgorithmID" is mixed in to the ECDH-ES KDF, so a fully specified algorithm would bind the resulting key similar to https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-housley-lamps-cms-cek-hkdf-sha256/

comments.author: OR13
comments.body: addressed in -03

issues.title: Considerations for KEMs
issues.author: OR13
issues.body:
KEMs are not defined for use in JOSE or COSE at the time we are writing the draft

We expect them to be defined soon, and we want to provide guidance that is consistent with both HPKE KEMs and non HPKE KEMs

https://www.iana.org/assignments/hpke/hpke.xhtml#hpke-kem-ids

DHKEM(P-384, HKDF-SHA384)

vs

id-mod-cms-rsa-kem-2023 

https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-lamps-rfc5990bis/

In general KEMs fit where previously we would have seen ECDH-ES or ECDH-SS

Fully specified KEMS have a fixed KDF internalized

Polymorphic KEMS parameterize the KDF.

pulls.title: WLGC Feedback on Encryption Algorithms
pulls.author: OR13
pulls.body:
This PR focuses on the WGLC feedback regarding what "fully specified encryption algorithm identifier" means.

The approach taken is to review the the modes of encryption supported by JOSE and COSE, and comment on the algorithms registered to support those modes, and explain what a fully specified algorithm for each mode would look like.

comments.body: Why is the KEMs section now commented out?

A local editor mistake, as you can see in the latest changes, I've restructured the entire section to focus on the encryption modes that JOSE and COSE support, and explain what fully specified means for each mode.
I think we should register a small number of fully-specified encryption algorithms, but I'm OK leaving this text as-is and changing it when we add those registrations.

I think that this is only partially correct.

Examples for each case:

- Key Agreement - https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7518#appendix-C
- Direct Encryption - https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7520#section-5.6.3

```suggestion
To convey a fully-specified Key Establishment (Key Agreement) algorithm, both the "alg" and "enc" values must be fully-specified, the closest example of this can be found in Appendix C of RFC7518, however the "alg" value lacks the explicit curve and key derivation function.
To convey a fully-specified Direct Encryption algorithm in JOSE, the "alg" value MUST be "dir",
```

pulls.title: Enable use of fully-specified ECDH algorithms
pulls.author: selfissued
pulls.body:
Inventories ECDH possibilities in a new appendix.

Changes the terminology "Key Establishment and Direct Encryption" to "Key Establishment with Direct Encryption".

Say that fully-specified algorithms *specify*, rather than *include* all cryptographically relevant parameters.

Change the abstract and intro wording to align with our intent.

Registering a small number of fully-specified ECDH algorithms is the next step for this PR.

pulls.title: Improved description of why RSA was not updated
pulls.author: selfissued
pulls.body: Per John Mattson's comments

comments.body:
```suggestion
	  This document does not describe or request registration of any fully specified RSA algorithms. Some RSA signing implementations, such as
	  FIPS-compliant Hardware Security Modules (HSMs) <xref target="FIPS.140-3"/>
	  limit RSA key parameters to specific values with acceptable security characteristics.
	  This approach could be extended to define fully specified RSA algorithms in the future.
```

```suggestion
	  This approach could be extended to define fully-specified RSA algorithms in the future.
```

Despite the substantial simplification of the encryption section, I tried to have the statements that remain be statements that we already made in the much longer previous section, so as not to be introducing new text from whole cloth not previously reviewed by the working group.

The one (short) new piece of text that I added was where I said that HSS-LMS is polymorphic, which John Mattsson had asked us to include.

pulls.title: Attempt to address secdir review
pulls.author: OR13
pulls.body: https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/jose/aik5pnFfPLwP7CnFdxWOm3pFUYY/

comments.body:
```suggestion
      <t>
Note that there may be attacks possible with polymorphic algorithms
when the attacker is the party producing a signature.
In this case, the attacker using a polymorphic signature algorithm could vary
the actual algorithm used by changing some of the algorithm parameters
that are not fully-specified by the polymorphic algorithm identifier.
While the signature with different parameters would still be valid,
the recipient might not support the necessary algorithm parameters to validate it.
These kinds of attacks are not possible with fully-specified algorithms.
      </t>
```

Attempt to address Kathleen's second comment.

```suggestion
      </t>
      <t>
Note that there may be attacks possible with polymorphic algorithms
when the attacker is the party producing a signature.
In this case, the attacker using a polymorphic signature algorithm could vary
the actual algorithm used by changing some of the algorithm parameters
that are not fully-specified by the polymorphic algorithm identifier.
While the signature with different parameters would still be valid,
the recipient might not support the necessary algorithm parameters to validate it.
These kinds of attacks are not possible with fully-specified algorithms.
      </t>
```

I moved your suggestion from here: https://github.com/ietf-wg-jose/draft-ietf-jose-fully-specified-algorithms/pull/30/files#r2023852204

So we can keep both, and unpack them with more clarity
This text has been added as its own section.

```suggestion
  <t>
	An "attack signature" is a unique pattern or characteristic used to identify malicious activity, enabling systems to detect and respond to known threats. 
	The digital signature and key establishment algorithms used by software can contribute to an attack signature.
	By varying the identifier used for an algorithm, some sofware systems may attempt to evade rule based detection and classification.
	Rule based detection and classification systems may need to update their rules to account for fully specified algorithms.
	These systems should be aware that writing rules for polymorphic algorithms is more difficult, as each variant of the algorithm must be accounted for.
	For example, ES384 in COSE might be used with 3 different keys, each with a different curve.
      </t>
```

```suggestion
	By varying the identifier used for an algorithm, some sofware systems may attempt to evade rule-based detection and classification.
	Rule-based detection and classification systems may need to update their rules to account for fully-specified algorithms.
```

pulls.title: Apply suggestions by Mike Bishop and Paul Wouters
pulls.author: selfissued
pulls.body: Cc: @MikeBishop @paulwouters

comments.body:
```suggestion
	It deprecates all presently registered polymorphic algorithm identifiers.
```

The wording "It deprecates all presently registered polymorphic algorithm identifiers." would be misinterpreted.  We don't deprecate all registered polymorphic algorithm identifiers.  We only deprecate those for which we register replacement algorithms, hence the "those".

For instance, we don't deprecate "ECDH-ES".
